Then there was a large woman with black eyes and an abundance of raven hair, that kept bustling in and out of the bed-chamber with a look of happy importance, that made her strong features quite handsome. You would hardly have recognized the prison woman, in that neatly clad rosy cheeked female, the expression and whole appearance was so changed. Home and care had done everything for her, and at this time she was housekeeper in the mansion. Had you asked her character of the old ladies who found an asylum there, the account would have astonished you. After all, where real strength of character exists, there is always hope of reformation. It is your weak sinner for whom one despairs the most. As this woman passed through the room, she always turned her eyes, beaming with fondness, on a little boy, half concealed by the flow of Mrs. Gray's gown. It was quite wonderful how much that gown could shelter; and the mother spoke in that glance eloquently as ever love was uttered in words.

Then there was Jacob Strong himself, with a new coat in its first gloss, too short for his long arms, and cut after a fashion of his own, which made him look more round-shouldered and ungainly than ever. A buff vest, and gloves of a deeper yellow, gave an air of peculiar smartness to his costume, which bespoke some very important occasion; for it was not often that Jacob gave way to weaknesses regarding his toilet; and when he did, the effect was indisputably striking.

Besides the persons we have mentioned, were a score of nice aged women in snowy caps and chintz dresses, looking the very pictures of contented old age, who whispered cosily together, and watched a door that led to the stairs with the greatest interest, as if some very important person was expected to enter from that way.

Their impatience was gratified at last; for a clergyman with flowing robes came sweeping through, escorted by Jacob Strong, who had been wandering about the dim vestibule during the last ten minutes. Directly after, the room opposite was flung open, and Robert Otis came forth, leading a fair young girl by the hand. There was something heavenly in the loveliness of that gentle bride, as the blush deepened and faded away beneath the gossamer sheen of her veil.

Jacob Strong rubbed his yellow gloves softly together, as he gazed upon her; and the rustle of Mrs. Gray's dress was absolutely eloquent of all the restless pride she felt in seeing the two beings she most loved united for ever.

Of all the persons present, Ada Leicester alone was sad. She remembered her own marriage, and the shadow of many a painful thought swept across her face, as the solemn benediction was uttered over her child.

When the ceremony was complete Florence arose, and quietly placing a folded paper in the lap of the bride, stole away, as if terrified by the strange eyes that followed her movement. Julia took up the paper, half unfolded it, and then, with a blush and a smile, placed it in the hand of her young husband. With that paper Florence had conveyed two thirds of her fine property to the daughter of William Leicester-the man who had swept every blossom from the pathway of her own life.

div.head: A BOOK FOR EVERY PROTESTANT.
Carlington Castle;
OR, THE WILES OF JESUITISM.
BY C. G. H.
AUTHOR OF "CURATE OF LINWOOD," "AMY HARRINGTON," ETC., ETC.
div.p: 1 vol. 12mo., 334 pp. Cloth, gilt, 75 cts., paper, 50 cts.

This volume is said to present a thrilling picture of the sufferings and trials of one whose tender frame might well have yielded to a frightful accumulation of horrors, had not an abiding faith and an exalted moral courage preserved her through her trials. It is impossible to become acquainted with instances of such lofty fortitude, as evinced by the heroine of this book, without a thrill of admiration, or to read the atrocities and cruelties that were inflicted upon her, without a feeling of almost vehement indignation.-Saturday Philadelphia Courier.

The incidents are said to be true, and dealing with such subjects as Jesuit priests, it would be strange if the author had not wrought an exciting tale. All is wheat that comes to that mill. No ingenuities of imagination nor fire of description can surpass the real deeds of such men.-New York Evangelist.

This highly interesting work reveals the deceitful art and devices extensively practised by Roman Catholic priests to aggrandize their communion. The revelation of its art, presented in this tale, will be read with intense interest.-Christian Observer, Philadelphia.

Let us never forget that characters such as the Count and Father Adien have existed in every European Romish country, or wherever Jesuitism is to be found; and let us learn the more to love and defend those immortal principles of truth of which they would rob mankind.-Churchman's Magazine.

div.head: AN ORIGINAL AMERICAN ROMANCE.
Annie Grayson;
OR, LIFE IN WASHINGTON.
BY MRS N. P. LASSELLE.
div.p: Complete in one vol. 12mo. 345 pages, cloth, 75 cts., paper 50cts.

"The aim of the fair authoress seems to have been to impress upon the young mind the danger of giving the heart up to a love of pleasure and outward display. She seems to have been extremely happy in the attainment of her object, and has been successful in producing a very entertaining volume."-New-Bedford Standard.

"We should judge it to be not only a good representation of the prominent phases of society in Washington, but well calculated to convey to the young heart the danger of giving itself up to a love of pleasure and outward display."-Springfield Republican.

"It is designed to show off the peculiarities of fashionable society in that city, and at the same time to impress the value of a life of piety in contrast to a life of pleasure."-New York Literary Gazette.

"'ANNIE GRAYSON.'-Such is the modest title of a new and deeply interesting American novel, by Mrs. N. P. Lasselle-a novel founded upon real incidents, most of which transpired amid the circles of the fictitious society of Washington city. We have seldom read a work with a better relish-the characters being boldly and truthfully drawn-knowing as we do the extreme vulnerability of fashionable life at the capital."-Boston Mail.

div.head: A NOVEL OF METROPOLITAN LIFE.
Violet:
THE CHILD OF THE CITY.
BY ROBERT F. GREELEY.
div.p: One vol., 12mo., 300 pages; cloth 75cts.; paper 50cts.

A very excellent story, this. A fine and genial tone prevades the whole work. Pictures both of city and country life are drawn in a graphic and most attractive manner. Violet, the heroine, is a charming creature, the semblance of which we sometimes find in real life, and always to bless and refine. The more we can have of such works the better. They aid morality, society, Christianity. The various characters are vigorously drawn and skilfully managed.-Boston Bee.

A very readable book. It portrays city life in a sprightly, graphic and generally truthful manner, contrasting with considerable power the exciting and grotesque scenes of the great metropolis with that quiet stilness and comparative freedom from care peculiar to the country. We should not wonder if some of the characters in "VIOLET" proved real-particularly the "Benedicts." However this may be, it contains types which will be readily recognized, and perhaps nearer home than the scene of the tale.-Philadelphia Daily News.

The writer of this work has taken up a subject that we have long wanted to see presented to the young, who are yearning to forsake the quiet joys and pure air of the country, for the dust, and toil, and temptations of a city life. The author says his design has been to exhibit in strong colors the contrast between the life of town and country, and the harrowing cares and vicissitudes which so many daily exchange for the free air and healthy employment of the woods and fields. The variety of characters introduced, and the spirit with which they are handled, render this work of no inconsiderable interest. Some of the scenes are worthy the very best productions of the day.-Philadelphia Saturday Courier.

div.head: A BOOK FOR EVERY AMERICAN.
THE Romance of the Revolution;
BEING A HISTORY OF THE PERSONAL ADVENTURES, HEROIC EXPLOITS AND ROMANTIC INCIDENTS, AS ENACTED IN THE WAR OF INDEPENDENCE.
div.p: One vol., large 12mo., 450 pages. Cloth, gilt, price $1 50.
BEAUTIFULLY ILLUSTRATED.

"An eminently readable collection of narratives of remarkable events in the American war of Independence, illustrated by a number of neatly executed wood cuts. Some of the incidents related give a painfully vivid impression of the horrors of war, whilst others exhibit the highest developments of courage, fortitude and patriotism. The perusal of such records must stimulate national spirit, and enliven our gratitude to those who suffered so much to achieve the liberties we now enjoy. The work is handsomely printed, and bound suitably for a gift book."-Commercial Advertiser.
"No one can read it without a more vivid conception of the heroism of the patriots who achieved the liberty of the country."-N. Y. Tribune.
"The leading illustration, 'Escape of Marion,' is of the kind we like to see, as it places before us vividly the dauntless spirit and cool possession of the hero."-Philadelphia Post.

"We are always glad to note the attention paid to our gallant and patriotic fathers, who perilled their lives and their fortunes in securing the magnificent legacy which they have bequeathed to our keeping. Books like these, keep alive the memory of their heroic deeds, and give to the rising generation a more lively insight into the days of trial and blood through which our fathers struggled."-Philadelphia Saturday Courier.

div.head: A CHARMING PICTURE OF AUSTRALIAN LIFE.
My Home in Tasmania,
DURING A RESIDENCE OF NINE YEARS.
BY MRS. CHARLES MEREDITH.
div.p: ILLUSTRATED WITH BEAUTIFUL ENGRAVED VIEWS OF THE FOLLOWING POINTS OF INTEREST: Hobarton, Poyston, Deloraine Bridge, Entrance to Port Arthur, Spring Vale Cottage, Tasman Island, and Cape Pillar.
Complete in one 12mo. volume of 370 pages. Price $1 25.

"She is equally at home in her portraiture of the comparative refinement of the colonial capitals, or in the more exciting scenes of adventure encountered during her residence in remote settlements, all of which she depicts in an animated, unpretentious style, at once fresh and evidently truthful. The natural productions of the country, the habits, manners, and mode of living of the colonists, are described with great skill and power of observation, making the book an interesting compendium of valuable information."-Home Journal.
"It is a work of uncommon interest, written in a spirit of cheerfulness and vivacity, and abounds with information of great value."-New York Tribune.

"The simplicity and liveliness of the style, the variety and interest of its incident, the authentic information it conveys, will ensure it a large circulation among eager readers."-Knickerbocker Magazine.
"To those who take interest in the every-day crosses of housekeeping, the book will be attractive for its admirable descriptions of the birds of the air and the beasts of the forest."-Evening Post.
"The style is finished and attractive, and the whole tone of the book ladylike and free from affectation-it is a deeply interesting volume"-Baltimore American.

div.head: "HAVE WE A BOURBON AMONG US?"
THE Lost Prince:
FACTS TENDING TO PROVE THE IDENTITY OF LOUIS THE SEVENTEENTH OF FRANCE AND THE REV. ELEAZAR WILLIAMS, MISSIONARY AMONG THE INDIANS IN NORTH AMERICA.
BY THE REV. JOHN H. HANSON.
div.p: One vol. 12mo. With three Portraits. 480 pages. Cloth $1 25.
"There is no escape from the conclusion that the Rev. Eleazar Williams is the son of Louis XVI. It is impossible to impair the force of such accumulated evidence."-Rev. C. Colton, D. D.

"The book must be carefully read in order to form any just idea of the nature of the testimony, which is so involved and varied, and united together by so many delicate links, that it is quite impossible, in a brief space, to give anything like a fair synopsis of it.

"Apart altogether from the interest excited by the main question of identity, the book will be found full of important historical information, gathered from numerous sources, combined with no little skill."-Putnam's Monthly.

"We believe that if this question involved an inheritance of a few millions of dollars, there would be lawyers enough in the United States able and willing to undertake its conduct on the faith of the case here credibly made out."-Albion.

"Assuredly a literary curiosity; what makes the curiosity still more curious is the large mass of circumstantial evidence, and even (if it be all authentic) positive evidence that this diligent Missionary is indeed the true Prince."-Citizen.
